stem: Based on the provided information, which intervention is the MOST appropriate to implement *immediately*?

itemContext.sbar: S: Ricardo Alvarez, 78-year-old male, admitted 3 days ago for a UTI. He is now exhibiting signs of sepsis. 07:00: Patient reported feeling 'weak and dizzy.' B: History of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Initial UTI treated with oral ciprofloxacin. U: 07:15: Patient's current vital signs: Temp 102.5°F (39.2°C), HR 120 bpm, RR 28, BP 88/52 mmHg, SpO2 92% on 2L nasal cannula. Labs show WBC 15,000/μL, Lactate 3.5 mmol/L. Urine culture pending, but patient is producing scant, dark, concentrated urine (30 mL/hr). A: Patient is hypotensive, tachycardic, and febrile, suggestive of sepsis secondary to possible antibiotic-resistant UTI. R: I recommend immediate initiation of IV fluids, obtaining blood cultures prior to administering broad-spectrum antibiotics (excluding penicillin derivatives), and escalation of care to the ICU for closer monitoring and potential vasopressor support.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: WBC: 15,000/μL (High); Lactate: 3.5 mmol/L (High); Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL (High); BUN: 35 mg/dL (High); Urine Culture: Pending; Blood Culture: Not Drawn

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Ciprofloxacin 500mg PO BID (Last dose 06:00); Acetaminophen 650mg PO PRN for fever > 101°F (38.3°C) (Not Administered); Normal Saline IV at 20 mL/hr (Infusion in Progress)

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 07:15: Temp: 102.5°F (39.2°C); HR: 120 bpm; RR: 28; BP: 88/52 mmHg; SpO2: 92% on 2L NC; Urine Output: 30 mL/hr

options.content: Increase the rate of the current normal saline IV infusion.
Discontinue the ciprofloxacin due to suspected resistance.
Prepare for immediate insertion of an indwelling urinary catheter.

rationale.correct: Increasing the rate of the current normal saline IV infusion is the most immediate and crucial intervention. The patient presents with hypotension (88/52 mmHg), tachycardia (120 bpm), and elevated lactate (3.5 mmol/L), all indicative of sepsis-induced hypoperfusion. Rapid fluid resuscitation is the cornerstone of initial sepsis management to improve blood pressure and tissue perfusion. While other interventions are also necessary, addressing the hypovolemia is the priority to stabilize the patient.
rationale.incorrect: Administering acetaminophen addresses the fever but does not directly address the life-threatening hypotension and hypoperfusion associated with sepsis. Discontinuing ciprofloxacin may be necessary later based on culture results, but immediate hemodynamic stabilization takes precedence. Inserting an indwelling urinary catheter will provide more accurate urine output monitoring, but it is not the priority in the initial management of sepsis. Fluid resuscitation comes first.
clinicalPearls: Sepsis is a time-sensitive emergency requiring rapid assessment and intervention.
The 'Surviving Sepsis Campaign' guidelines emphasize the importance of early fluid resuscitation and antibiotic administration within the first hour of sepsis recognition.
Monitor urine output closely as an indicator of renal perfusion and fluid resuscitation effectiveness.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting acetaminophen seems reasonable because of the fever, but it overlooks the more critical issue of hypotension and hypoperfusion.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on the immediate threat to the patient's life. Remember the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and address circulatory issues first in sepsis management.

mnemonic.title: SEPSIS
mnemonic.expansion: Source identification, Early antibiotics, Push fluids, Pressors if needed, Individualized care, Serial lactate measurements, Support organ function.
